description.text: A snow-covered landscape with several houses, trees, snow and a full moon, in an Eid greeting card. The Urdu text reads: "Assalamo alaikum, Eid Mubarak!"

inscription.text: برادر مکرم و معظّم جناب شفیق الدین صاحب السلام علیکم عید مبارک - آپ تو بالکل خاموش رہتے ہیں . کبھی کبھار اپنی اور گھر کی خیریت سے اطلاع دیدیا کریں - میری طرف سے بھابھی صاحبہ اور شفیع الدین کو سلام دیں - قبلہ والدہ صاحبہ اور والد صاحب کو سلام . سمیع الدین کو دعا . فقط رفیق الدین

Biradar-e-mokarram wa mo'azzam janab Shafiquddin sahib, Assalamo alaikum, Eid Mubarak! Aap to bilkul khamosh rahte hain, kabhi kabhar apni aur ghar ki khairiyat se ittila de diya karen. Meri taraf se bhabhi sahiba aur Shafiuddin ko salam den. Qibla walida saheba aur walid saheb ko salam. Samiuddin ko dua. Faqat, Rafiquddin.

My dear elder and exalted brother Mr.Shafiquddin, May peace be upon you, and greetings of Eid. You remain so quiet! Please keep us updated occasionally with the situation of the family. Please give my regards to the sister-in-law and Shafiuddin. Also my regards to the exalted mother and father, and prayers for Samiuddin. Yours Rafiquddin. (ys)

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

ext:item.ext:value: description-en: A snow-covered landscape with several houses, trees, snow and a full moon, in an Eid greeting card. The Urdu text reads: "Assalamo alaikum, Eid Mubarak!" (gs)

text-ur: برادر مکرم و معظّم جناب شفیق الدین صاحب السلام علیکم عید مبارک - آپ تو بالکل خاموش رہتے ہیں . کبھی کبھار اپنی اور گھر کی خیریت سے اطلاع دیدیا کریں - میری طرف سے بھابھی صاحبہ اور شفیع الدین کو سلام دیں - قبلہ والدہ صاحبہ اور والد صاحب کو سلام . سمیع الدین کو دعا . فقط رفیق الدین

text-transcription-ur: Biradar-e-mokarram wa mo'azzam janab Shafiquddin sahib, Assalamo alaikum, Eid Mubarak! Aap to bilkul khamosh rahte hain, kabhi kabhar apni aur ghar ki khairiyat se ittila de diya karen. Meri taraf se bhabhi sahiba aur Shafiuddin ko salam den. Qibla walida saheba aur walid saheb ko salam. Samiuddin ko dua. Faqat, Rafiquddin.

text-translation-ur: My dear elder and exalted brother Mr.Shafiquddin, May peace be upon you, and greetings of Eid. You remain so quiet! Please keep us updated occasionally with the situation of the family. Please give my regards to the sister-in-law and Shafiuddin. Also my regards to the exalted mother and father, and prayers for Samiuddin. Yours Rafiquddin. (ys)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The Priya Paul collection has several used and unused Eid cards, mostly published in 1930-40s in Lahore, that feature culturally alien images imported from Europe, stamped with messages of Eid greetings in Urdu. (Yousuf Saeed) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The fact that many of [the Eid cards] depict snow-clad European winter with alpine trees suggests that they were meant to be used for Christmas. But a simple stamping of Urdu/Arabic phrases Eid mubarak or Assalamu-aleikum (salutation) on such a landscape, along with poetic messages at the back, made them suitable as a novelty for local Eid celebration. Most of these refurbished Eid cards are (re)produced by publishers such as Hafiz Qamruddin & Sons, H.Ghulam Mohammad & Sons, and Mohammad Hussain & Bros, all running their business from the famous Mochi gate area of Lahore’s walled city, a sort of a cultural district not only for the artists and book publishers but also for music and food until today. (Yousuf Saeed) (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: There is text on the back side of the postcard, written in Urdu.

related literature: Mathur, Saloni, "Wanted Native Views: Collecting colonial postcards of India," in Antionette Burton (ed.) Gender, Sexuality and Colonial Modernities, New York: Routledge, 1999, 95-115. (gs)
related literature: Patterson, Steven, Postcards from the Raj, Patterns of Prejudice, Volume 40, Number 2, Routledge, May 2006, 142-158; also see Saloni Mathur, 1999. (gs)

related hyperlinks: http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/117/index_1.html, last accessed 2011-04-04, online essay "Eid Mubarak: Cross-cultural Image Exchange in Muslim South Asia." by Yousuf Saeed (gs)

related literature: Wehbe, Rana, Seeing Beirut through Colonial Postcards: A Charged Reality, (undated) American University of Beirut, Lebanon, http://webfea.fea.aub.edu.lb/proceedings/2004/SRC-ArD-01.pdf (gs)
Patterson, Steven, Postcards from the Raj, Patterns of Prejudice, Volume 40, Number 2, Routledge, May 2006, 142-158; also see Saloni Mathur, 1999.
Wehbe, Rana, Seeing Beirut through Colonial Postcards: A Charged Reality, (undated) American University of Beirut, Lebanon, http://webfea.fea.aub.edu.lb/proceedings/2004/SRC-ArD-01.pdf
Mathur, Saloni, "Wanted Native Views: Collecting colonial postcards of India," in Antionette Burton (ed.) Gender, Sexuality and Colonial Modernities, New York: Routledge, 1999, 95-115.
online essay "Eid Mubarak: Cross-cultural Image Exchange in Muslim South Asia." by Yousuf Saeed

The fact that many of [the Eid cards] depict snow-clad European winter with alpine trees suggests that they were meant to be used for Christmas. But a simple stamping of Urdu/Arabic phrases Eid mubarak or Assalamu-aleikum (salutation) on such a landscape, along with poetic messages at the back, made them suitable as a novelty for local Eid celebration. Most of these refurbished Eid cards are (re)produced by publishers such as Hafiz Qamruddin & Sons, H.Ghulam Mohammad & Sons, and Mohammad Hussain & Bros, all running their business from the famous Mochi gate area of Lahore’s walled city, a sort of a cultural district not only for the artists and book publishers but also for music and food until today.
There is text on the back side of the postcard, written in Urdu.

The Priya Paul collection has several used and unused Eid cards, mostly published in 1930-40s in Lahore, that feature culturally alien images imported from Europe, stamped with messages of Eid greetings in Urdu.
